analysis: Isoniazid is an antibiotic commonly used in the treatment of tuberculosis. It is well-documented in medical literature that isoniazid can interfere with the metabolism of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine). This interference occurs because isoniazid forms a complex with pyridoxal phosphate, the active form of vitamin B6, leading to its increased excretion and reduced availability in the body. As a result, patients on isoniazid therapy are at risk of developing vitamin B6 deficiency, which can manifest as peripheral neuropathy, among other symptoms. This is a widely accepted and well-understood interaction in pharmacology, making vitamin B6 deficiency the most likely to be observed in patients taking isoniazid.
